Along Jefferson to Embacardero, you will hit along many gift shops and small stands that sells quick fish and chips. If you ever get a chance to hit towards Maritime National Park, this stand is one of my pit stop to get some yummy nourishment.
author: Mike L.

description: After browsing different seafood stands, decided on this on. Got the fried calamari (usually comes with fries but asked for them without fries so they just gave us more calamari). Very generous portions. the calamari was tender and crispy. Really good with lemon and sauce that it comes with. M's got a cup of their clam chowder which also was really good...it definitely was not from the can! Next time I plan on getting the lobster roll. It looked so good but we were so stuffed.
author: Jocelyn B.

description:
Re: clam chowder in bread bowl.  typical boudin sourdough bread.Did I detect bacon? For me, the bacony flavour was nice but a miss at the same time because it didn't quite suffice the clam craving .  The chowder itself, was lacking in clam meat *sad face here.  Also the potatoes were nice and soft - not mushy.  I liked the simple seasoning and the accent flavours created by the celery but seriously could've had more of a clam presence (it is clam chowder, after all.)  

Probably more deserving of 2 stars but because taste testing clam chowders is so much fun to do especially when comparing to 2 other foodstands, its gonna get a 3... yup having friends and having each have a different bowl to compare together is the way to go....
author: Malalini S.

description: I tried their clam chowder in sourdough and there were too much random veggies, barely any clam or other meats. The soup itself is also a bit too salty. Out of all the clam chowder places around, I would not choose this one.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Wanted some fresh seafood, so my friend and I made a trip to the over priced touristy Fisherman's Wharf. These places can be pretty fun when you get some small grub and eat it overlooking the water.

We got the shrimp and crab cocktail and the crab cake. A small cup packed with fresh crab meat, bay shrimp, and topped with two regular shrimp. Accompanied by a couple lemon wedges and cocktail sauce, it was a tasty snack. The crab cake was delicious. A fresh crab meat mixture, deep fried to crunchy perfection, it was perfectly seasoned! It was accompanied by fries (mediocre), a packet of tartar sauce, and a packet of ketchup.

I don't know if I'll be back anytime soon, but it was fun to do since I can't remember the last time I played tourist out on the wharf!
author: Leana L.

description:
Clam Chowder bread bowl - bland and they skimped on the seafood (never again)
Fried Calamari - warm, slightly crispy, good portion, not rubbery, and decent (wouldn't mind getting it again)
Crab sandwich - terrible... It was cold crab with mayo or whatever sauce on a rock hard baguette that probably was sitting in the fridge all day

Overall I would never go again. The service was speedy but the soup and the sandwich stinks and calamari isn't enough to complete a meal.
author: Jenny L.

description: Calamari and chips... Delicious. Clam chowder was really good, but I've had better. Crab cocktail was really good warmed up.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Chinese restaurant owners are everywhere! 

Bread bowl clam chowda was really yummy and filling! with some hot sauce it was even better! chunky clams and creamy chowda mmm mmmm yum! 

Craving some right now!!!
author: Natalia H.

description: Based on the reviews I expected my crab sandwich to be fair at best.  In reality it was a solid 4 out of 5 stars. For some reason the line here was shorter than the neighbor who has 3.5 stars on Yelp. Next time I will try the neighbor just to see the difference.
author: Jeff S.

description:
was visiting SF and Pier 39 was one of the  areas we wanted to check out... parking is pretty hard to find unless you don't mind paying for parking in a lot.. 

anyways.. i ordered the all items which was like $17.. it includes breaded shrimp, fried fish fillet , french fries, calamari, and clam strips... probably the worst calamari i ever had.. it was rubberish... the clam strip was chewing.. average fries that you can get anywhere.. however i did enjoy the fried fish fillet and the breaded shrimp.. 

i also ordered a cup of clam chowder and it was just OK... nothing special about it..

if i was to ever come back.. i would just order the fish fillet and breaded shrimp!
author: Darren F.

description: super good crab!!! Fresh and tasty!! The clam chowder is worthy to try and pretty yummy~~ also not expensive~~ love to go~ will go San Francisco several more times for clam chowder （＾＾）
author: Liyuan J.

description: The clam chowder is delicious and they are not overpriced!! I also enjoyed their FRESH steamed crabs with butter. But then I don't think you can go wrong with clam chowder or crab anywhere on Fishermen's Wharf!
author: Lynn T.

description:
1. Too much mayonnaise in the crab sandwich.
2. Calamari-- not fresh at all.
author: Trang B.

description:
Calamari n chips.

Seriously. The calamari is so well seasoned, breaded, fried beautifully. OMG. so good. the calamari it self is so fresh, soft like butter (but cooked and not overcooked), and not fishy.

The sauce as a side is also a good accompaniment, but I was focusing on my calamari and chips. YUMM!

Definitely a must try !
author: Kenny W.

description:
So my friend told me about this place for seafood - a small shop on Fisherman's Dwarf, a little dirty, cheap, fresh seafood, always crowded, and filled with hungry customers. I thought "okay, let's go check it out tomorrow." So we went the next day for lunch and this place was filled with hungry seafood lovers already. I know there are lots of seafood restaurants on Fisherman's Dwarf that offer clean, beautiful, and comfortable environment but charge you like no tomorrow. (Been there, done that.) Yes, Crab Station #2 is not as pretty as other but they will keep you wanting more of their seafood. 
Personally, I am not so crazy about fried food so I would give their fried seafood 3 stars. However, their chowder, lobster, crab, oyster, and sandwiches are SO SO GOOD. This place is a must try for all seafood lovers.
author: Amiel C.

description:
I really have experienced better. Their clam chowder bread bowl was so small and the bread on the inside were still intact which means less soup. Their clam chowder really wasn't all that good. It lacked the creaminess that clam chowder is famous for. We also ordered the calamari and chips. I'll admit that these were the biggest calamari I have ever seen but it lacked flavor. Their marinara sauce was not good at all. Packets of tartar sauce was even worse. Their crab salad sandwich was a huge waste of money. It was cold and the bread was old. It had little parts of the shell in it which cut my palette. 

Huge disappointment.
author: Serena F.

description:
I wish I would have not gone to Pier 39, for the food that is. 

Shrimp - n - Chips 
Calamari - n - Chips

Came here after eating at Swiss Louis Restaurant on Pier 39 which for the price just wasn't worth it . NOW back to the Crab Station don't know what to say. Great portions, really good flavor. Was there 10/12/13 at around 9pm place was busy. Four of us where there, we all loved it. Won't hesitate going there again. I'm elling all my fellow Angelinos to go try there food. Loved it...
author: Edgar T.

description:
Had to hit this area as my father in law was visiting and this was his first time in SF and the Wharf.  The clam chowder bread bowl was fresh and almost too much bread, however they enjoyed it!  We walked around the corner to find a place to sit and eat, or really it ended up being stand and eat but that is part of the fun!

Don't forget (like I did) to get your parking ticket validated if you parked in the lot across the street!!
author: Carolyn C.

description:
4.9 for this! Love the crab station.  Fresh seafood and tasty clam chowder!  Every time I'm visiting SF, Pier 39 Crab station is always the spot to hang out, then off to other location.

In that lil' strip, there you can find all types of seafood dishes the only con's from giving this place a 5 star is that it can be crowded and there is no place to sit.  It's like a first come first serve thing and when you can't sit and enjoy your food, it makes it suck and inconvenient

Other than that- great place and great food.
author: Mali T.

description: The eating place is very simple looking and doesn't look very clean. But how's the crab? Delicious...
author: C G.

description:
I take forever to pick out a spot to have a bread bowl of clam chowder.. even though I've been here many times..

We decided on Crab Station #2.. they were the loudest to promote their stuff, so why not. We ordered the clam chowder bread bowl, crab cakes and chips, a live crab and a cup of clam chowder later on because I ate most of it.

Dude, the single crab was $18+! Geeeeeeeeeeez! It must have been good because Dude enjoyed it very much.

Clam Chowder was OK - we had a lot of bread left.. I think I'd rather just get a cup of chowder and order some bread on the side. The bread bowl is just fancy stuff. The crab cakes were OK.. I wish it was warmer and crispier.. but because we're at a booth and it was pre-made, that wasn't going to happen. Fries were gross.. and I LOVE fries, but these fries were no bueno.

I should just go to Boudin's next time.
author: Jennie P.

description: Crabs, shrimp, calamari.  Everything was great, but the best is the crabs by the pound.  Stand at the counter at eat your heart out!!!!
author: Kerrie S.

description: I came here with a few friends and we wanted to get some crabs do we decided to order a whole crab. It was $31 for the whole crab but it was definitely delicious. We split it between three but we had already eaten before so we weren't as hungry but a very tasty crab.
author: Jason Y.

description:
This is one of the few stands that has their own seating right in front of their station. I remember buying crabs from a different vendor with nowhere to sit because the other shops won't let you sit inside unless you bought it from them. I didn't even know which shop belonged to which station. It was hard to even sit along those stone hedges because there's always bird poop everywhere. 

I forgot what my crab weighed or how much it cost me but it was freakin' delicious. I made my own little lemon/pepper sauce and it was so divine and all mineee. They also have tons of napkins and wet naps!
author: Dung N.

description: Never again! Save your money! The cashier was too busy talking to his friend that he rung up something we did not order, and then said he could not refund us. What?! So we were stuck with some crab cocktail and it was NOT worth $10. The only reason I am giving them 1 star was because their cans of beer were $3.75. Totally regret stopping here
author: Jennifer P.

description:
When my son and I were on vacation in San Francisco for Father's Day weekend, we stopped here after taking a sight seeing boat ride and it was a very enjoyable experience. I wouldn't say the food was the tastiest, but it was good. It may simply be that fresh and authentic food is less tasty than processed food because of the salt and sugar content. The experience as a whole, however, will never be forgotten. I'd say it is something you have to do when you go to visit San Francisco.

My son wanted a whole crab and, although I knew it would be expensive, there was no way I was going to deny him the experience. He is only 9 and he loved picking the crab apart. He had watched YouTube videos on how to disect the crabs prior to our vacation, so to watch him actually get to do it was fun. I got the clam chowder bread bowl and I too was happier with the experience than I was with the food. Honestly, I find the clam chowder bread bowl at Souplantation to be tastier, but then again, that may be because it is processed food at Souplantation

We ate our food at a public table and we had to deal with the low flying sea gulls that were waiting for us to either discard our food or to be in-attentive to it. Once again, this was a part of the fun. My son and I kept saying "mine, mine, mine" like in the movie "Finding Nemo". On thing is for sure; you cannot experience the views of Alcatraz Island and of the Golden Gate Bridge at Souplantation like you can at San Francisco's Fisherman's Warf. Enjoy.
author: David R.

description:
If you're in the Fisherman's Wharf area and want to avoid the tourist traps and overpriced "seafood", then Crab Station #2 might be the perfect stop. Nestled in between a few other food stalls, down the street from the Boudin Bakery and parking lot, this gem serves up some tasty clam chowder (which I think is served in a Boudin bread bowl) for only $5.50, which is almost half the price of the other restaurants around. 

It doesn't stop with the chowder though. Order up a whole crab (I got two last time for $12 & $13 each) and watch the master cracker break down your freshly steamed crab, then assemble it all on a plate for you with some lemons, a zesty, horseradish laden cocktail sauce and a crapload of napkins. The crabs tasted amazing and if you have any bread left from the bread bowl, use it to mop up the tasty roe that's left pooled up in your crab shell. 

For me, this is what SF seafood on the wharf is all about. Another great thing about this place is that you might be lucky enough to find a table or some chairs inside their restaurant (which is pretty cozy). The best seat in the house is the counter on the window facing out towards the street and the stalls. From there you can pig out on crab, listen to the constant cracking sound of crab shells being artfully broken and watch the pigeons greedily eyeballing the tourists food. Service here was speedy, even though it was packed and more importantly, everyone seemed to be enjoying their food. 

Well worth a visit if you're near the wharf.
author: Chris J.

description: I came here with friends, and one of famous breads here is soup in the bread. It looks very creative, and interesting. Never seen before. The price is expensive as well, because it's near the pier 39, make sense to have this price.
author: Dan Y.

description:
My original review is here... http://www.yelp.com/biz/fishermans-wharf-chowder-and-crab-sidewalk-stands-san-francisco#hrid:W0qRA0ghhQAlqgbvqdixuw before I  figured out the names of the stalls

2 - (Crab Station) Had a crab here since Guardino's ran out. 12.95/lb here. He got a little agitated when I told him I wanted it packed to go ( I really wonder what they do different other than wrap it up in paper instead of placing it on a plate). These guys were all Chinese... lol they were a bunch of grown men bitching in Chinese. Anyway, after getting our crab I saw another worker load the big boiling cauldron with frozen crab.. sigh... 

Chowder in bread bowl- also because Guardino's ran out (of bread bowls). The chowder was salty but it balanced out with the sourdough bread. Needs more chowder I'd say. The bread took up so much we didn't get much chowder. 

Calamari - nicely breaded, not overcooked and soft. One of the better calamari I have had in the US.
author: Heidi C.

description: After going on a foodie bender, I arrived at fishermans warf already uncomfortably full. The smell and sights of all the tasty seafood vendors made me wish there was room in my belly for more... But I knew I would be pushing my tummy into dangerously stuffed zone and with a 3+ mile walk still ahead of me it would be unwise (to say the least) to try to eat more.  But, I still wanted my seafood fix, darn it!  So, I ordered a crab sandwich to go as we were heading out of the wharf area to nosh on later in the evening. When we ate it back at the hotel room that evening I was very pleased.  The bread was thick and chewy but still soft.  The crab in the sandwich was fresh, moist and delicious. There were large chucks of meat in the crab salad mix... Clearly they didn't just use leftover scrap meat... They did it up right.  The portion of meat in the sandwich was very generous too..practically billowing out of the baguette with each tasty bite.  My only complaint was the crab salad was a little bland on seasonings.  It just needed a little more *zing* to earn a 5 star.  Other than that , the location was clean (we only visited the outside counter) the staff was nice , the prices were on par with other neighboring places (READ: this is San Fran and fisherman's wharf is a huge tourist destination..:.so you can bet everything in this area is gonna be overpriced!). So, overall a tasty sandwich that lacked a little on seasoning and was slightly overpriced (but not when compared to other nearby options) earns a 4 stars for me.
author: Marilyn C.

description:
I'm a vegetarian 362 days out of the year, and on the other 3 days, you can find me I voraciously nibbling a few teeny clam strips with my french fries and sourdough mini-loaf. My bf and I used to go by a fish shack on the beach in Malibu, but we haven't had fresh seafood in about a year at this point, so we decided to make an impromptu San Fran trip for dinner last night! 

We ordered all of the fried fish things plus bread and french fries. The fries were pretty meh, and the calamari was like whole baby adorable squids all sadly battered and fried, but the seafood was all obviously quite fresh, and I can't complain about my 5 or 6 yummy clam strips. The prices were about the same as we paid in Malibu, but they gave us quite a bit more food. The best part was the fast-pace of the employees who grab you off the pier if you wander by too slowly, the cramped tiny seats, and the general loud, dirty, dive-y, fun SF vibe that's a part of the city no matter where you go.

P.S. Parking in metered spaces is free after 7pm, don't be tempted by that $33 lot!
author: Angie O.

description:
We came in excited to order a myriad of clam chowder and seafood, but the staff's bad attitude led us out the door before we even ate. Their menu clearly states that their bread bowl costs $5.75, but when we ordered, the douchebag grossly grinned and told us the total would be $6.75 and sarcastically said the additional cost was tax. He totally tried to rip us off so we took our wallets and appetites elsewhere.

RUDE.
author: MyLinh P.

description:
I was pretty hungry so this review won't be completely subjective. I had chowder in a bread bowl and these are my observations:

The good:

-Good consistency
-Lots of clams
-Big bread bowl 
-$5.50

The ugly:

-The bread bowl still had a lot of bread in it
-a little starchy, could refine it a little more, but at that price point they don't need to.
author: Marc M.

description:
I wanted to get fish n' chips at a favorite spot while visiting the Wharf, but my kiddo really wanted crab. None of the Yelp reviews looked particularly encouraging, so I called my aforementioned favorite spot and asked where they recommended. The woman on the phone was super nice. She said to beware in almost all cases that the clam chowder is from a can and everything but the crab itself was previously frozen. Not surprised. 

When the man picked out the crab from a pile of supposedly whole crabs, I saw him put two things on the scale. I asked if it was one crab and he held it up to show me, but could see that one of the legs was separate. I didn't make a big deal out of it, even tho I thought it was a little shady.  It wasn't until after I ordered that it dawned on me that the crab wasn't totally fresh--it had already been cooked, and they only put it in the boiling water to heat it up. The fact that the meat stuck to the shell more than I'm used to, leads me to believe that it wasn't  fresh.The fries were disgusting, limp, and slightly grey. I asked them if I could get fresh fries and they obliged. They also offered wet naps after finishing up. Those two plusses brought them up from one star to two. 

The place is dirty and pigeons lurk and waddle under the outdoor stand. I suppose there's not much they can do to stop that, but it's gross. From now on, I'm leaving my crab indulgences to Half Moon Bay or Swan's.
author: Jen L.

description:
This is my go-to clam chowder craving spot. I've never been disappointed. I've actually driven all the way from Sacramento just to go here to satisfy my cravings.

The service is quick (if not overtly friendly), the food is great and cheap, and the surroundings are always interesting.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Me and my husbanddecided to yelp which places were good and came across Crab Station.  The suggestions were the crab sandwiches and clam chowder soup so we ordered one cup of clam choweder, one bread bowl and one crab cake.  
Behind this place is a very tiny indoor place you can eat at which belongs to the Crab Station.  Luckily it wasn't crowded and we found a table straight away.  

I found the clam chowder to be thin and watered down unlike many homemade clam chowders I've had before that are nice and thick.  I mentioned to my husband that there was hardly any clams and more potatoe in the soup.  

There was a counter beside us with bulk trays of soda and sitting on top I noticed 2 empty trays (bulk buy) of Campbells New England Clam Chowder sitting on the counter.  Could it be that the soup is not made from scratch and they just use cans of Campbells Clam Chowder?  I didn't want to believe what I saw, but when the soup is not thick and homemade tasting and there are empty trays of Campbells New England Clam Chowder sitting on the counter, what else is there to think?  

Overall I would not return to this place for Clam Chowder.  I'm very disappointed with the quality of what we ate and what I saw.
author: Rosetta C.

description: Meh...was hoping for better. The calamari was fresh and tender, but very greasy as well. I also nibbled on some of my wife's shrimp cocktail/crab combo. Also, not bad, but not awesome either.
author: Mark G.

description: Awesome place to get crab, calamari, and clam chowder! Love that they validate your parking ticket if you park in the nearby lots as well!
author: Angelic L.

description:
This place is one of the many options for clam chowder at Fisherman's Wharf. I must have tried The Crab Station at least twice prior to my last visit on random trips to Fisherman's Wharf. Those crab stands tend to be very competitve against one another, so its always a gamble on which one to choose.

This past Labor Day weekend, I went to buy a cup of clam chowder as a late-dinner/snack. Granted I did not buy the bread bowl (due to not being very hungry), I'd assumed the cup of clam chowder would be sufficient enough to satisfy my taste buds. However, I was pretty disappointed that I found way more POTATOES than CLAMS in my chowder! I did not order potato chowder, I ordered CLAM chowder - at Fisherman's Wharf!!! 

Definitely skipping this place the next time I make my way down to Fisherman's Wharf for some clam chowder...
author: Mari S.

description:
I'm unsure what I was expecting.

First- I am not really into the touristy areas. We were visiting SF and a couple of locals informed us that we should go to Crab Station #2. We felt like we should listen to them...because they are locals. Locals are always right, right?

The area is a tad overwhelming. It was really windy and we ate outside. Some of the clam choweder and beer spilled on my sweater due to the intense wind. I didn't mind that though.

The clam chowder was tasty. The sourdough bread is what really makes it though. That is INCREDIBLE. Totally worth it.

We were adviced to get a crab roll. I'm unsure what I was expecting- but I know it wasn't this. It was crab mixed with TONS OF MAYO. I was unable to eat it. It just tasted incredibly bland. I would skip on the roles and go straight for the chowder.

There might be better- but my body refused to try every single stand to find out.
author: Katherine C.

description: Gotta stop here to get some seafood of course! Parking is validated when eating at selected crab stations.  Prices are decent and food is fresh.  Probably spent about $70-$100 for 2 crabs, 2 chowder bowls, squid, and oysters.  Very tasty, but would taste better if I could have sat down to enjoy it.. Seating is very difficult.  I'd say service was good since this place is like a madhouse.
author: Dao N.

description:
The second stop on my self styled four stop lunch tour of the outdoor stands of Taylor Street.

Had the crab cocktail. A decent size portion of fresh crab and cocktail sauce. Good stuff.
author: Gregory C.

description: We are sorry to report that the quality has gone down from years past.  The fried shrimp was still good but the fries were so old they were nearly inedible and the calamari was so chewy we just gave it back to them
author: Dan G.

description: below average food. The clam chowder soup had no clams in it. All potatoes. The boys working the station were extremely pushy and loud. the fried shrimp was okay. Nothing fascinating and I kind of regret eating it. Wish i wasn't in a rush to grab something before my alcatrez tour or maybe I would have tried something bettter!
author: Anne C.

description:
NEVER COMING HERE AGAIN!!!

Unless you want to pay $6.00 for Campbells Canned Clam Chowder and eat seafood that comes pre-packaged then be my guest.  

I only happened to stumble on this fascinating discovery after ordering the breaded clam chowder bowl and fried calamari & shrimp ourselves.  As my wife and I were eating this curb side we were dumbfounded to see a dolly with a shipment of Campbells clam chowder soup, breaded calamari and shrimp roll up right in front of us.  As if someone was playing a silly joke on us.  

The funny thing was that the delivery was made directly to the front of the store and they left the shipment out as if they had nothing to hide.  I had to take pictures immediately on my iphone.

It's a good thing we didn't waste our money trying anything else because this place is an absolute fraud.  How dare they advertise selling fresh seafood when stuff comes from a box or can.  I didn't try the crab but I'm sure they've been dead for days.

Before writing this post I read a review below from someone saying "the clam chowder tasted just a bit like progresso canned soup."  If he only knew the truth.
author: Danny C.

description: They really give you, the bang for your buck. Although, I only ordered the fried calamari. It was massive! It was simply perfect. I can only assume that their variety of other selections are as good as their calamari. Order up a broosky & some good seafood and chill at the pier & u good for the day!
author: Johnny Y.

description: after coming here over the years, it seems the servers and clientele have shifted.  current price of crab ~$15/lb, side of cocktail and butter sauces.  probably better to just get your own at $8-10/lb in the store.
author: Rob C.

description: The whole dungeness crab was fresh but it was $40. Super expensive it feels like. For $40 I can get one in a restaurant seasoned. At least they have a small tiny shack restaurant that you can stand/sit and eat in.
author: Hayden P.

description: I did not try their crab but I did try their fried calamari.  Good portion but I would like it to be more crispy.
author: Kevin L.

description:
This is my fav of the four seafood stands in Fisherman's Wharf. I've never had a bad experience here, although I've only been here twice in my life haha. But hey my food memory is legit so your trust level should be maxed out. 

The clam chowder would taste exponentially better if they were served in WARMED sourdough bread bowls. Imagine being able to tear off strips of bread with ease and dunking it into the chowder. That's how it's done in Maine. 

If you want to challenge the champ, then you have to train like the champ. WARMED breadbowls is the key to the throne. 

Do the knowledge...
author: Nino R.

description:
I was entertaining my daughter playing tourist for the day.  We took the F Line down to Fishermans Wharf to check out the scenery.  After we passed up Boudin and I recommended McCormicks and Kuleto's, my wife said there's the famous Crab Station.

I said are you sure, we could go to Mc. and Kuletos.  So were at the sidewalk kiosk and I get a Crab Sandwich which was served on a paper tray cold with all this preformed pink stuff jammed into the bread.  Not exactly what I was expecting.  It looked like pepto bismal which was mixed with something foreign.

My wife got the bowl of clam chowder and my daughter got the fish and chips.  So we have our food, and realize no where to eat. You basically have to eat it at a 6inch counter attached to there kiosk with water and crap/dirt all over it.  

After a few bites of Disgusting crab sandwich, I noticed a small  microscopic piece of hair on my crab concoction.  I showed it to the kiosk guy and asked him if i could have something else.

I tried the fish and chips since my kid seamed to be enjoying them.  The fish was pretty dry or maybe it was still frozen a little bit.  The fries were not hot although they appeared like they had been cooked.

I then ordered an Anchor Steam which was the best part of my meal.  My wife had already left us to go sit on a stump of concrete across the street and didn't look too happy.

I feel bad for the tourist who have to eat this crap.  It doesn't give our city a good referral for what we are supposed to be known to have good food.  Now I understand  why  locals don't go down to Fishermans Wharf and Pier 39.
author: James H.

description: Place is dirty! OMG they sell food outside and tell you you can eat inside walls are ful of food
author: Tony V.

description: The crab is good and the options are ideal.  If you're not hitting the Warf once every couple years, you're missing out on some delightful food and experiences, this place being one of them.
author: Otto D.

description:
Whenever I'm in Fisherman's Wharf I like to get a crab cocktail.  For some reason, this is the station I end up patronizing (unless I end up getting one at Pier 39 but that's totally a different matter).  I can't say why exactly I pick this stand (other than maybe that it's Chinese-run), that seems to be the case.

Anyway, I'm not sure the last time I patronized one of their neighboring stands for a comparison, nor do I find myself out here that often (maybe once or twice at most a year).  I'm leaving a rating to say they provide good service and the crab cocktail is quite enjoyable.  Last week I had a chance to be out here due to job site visits nearby, hence my chance to order and enjoy the delicacy.
author: H K.

description: I love this place. Everytime I come to SF I always have to stop by to satisfy my crab craving. Order the whole crab, share with another person (or not), sit down and enjoy. If you're looking to eat at the actual place though try to get someone to save a seat while you're ordering cause seating is pretty limited
author: Geoffrey T.

description: Seafood here is on point. There isn't many seats to sit at though. It's pretty difficult to eat crab or lobster while standing up. However, I was able to secure a seat after a little wait. Ordered the clam chowder and it was pretty good but I thought it was a little bit too salty. The girlfriend also got clam chowder in a bread bowl and thought it was solid. Someone else I was with ordered the lobster and crab. The lobster and crab were both pre-cracked meaning that their shells were already cracked for you to access the meat easier. The lobster and crab were both very good.
author: Thien-Tu T.

description: Haven't had steamed seafood several months. That's possibly a reason why i came to SF. Crab is a must try. Preferred to enjoy food stands rather than a formal restaurant looks like. One crab a box of prawn(shrimp cocktail ?), squid and soda, totally $40, amazing and delicious . A little bit salty on crab. A minor weakness is that the crab is cooked but i don't know when they cooked but anyway it tasted fresh.
author: Joyce L.

description: I've only eaten at the seafood stand they have set up outside, not in the restaurant.  My experience was satisfying enough, but far from memorable.  This place is owned and run by Asians (I think they are Mainland Chinese because I was speaking to them in Mandarin).  For the most part, their seafood is pretty fresh.  The prices are on par with the rest of the four stands in the area.  I feel that the raw oysters and crab are a bit fresher at Sabella & La Torres, which is two stands down.  At the same time, they offer a huge variety of fried seafood goods, including fried clams, fried calamari, and fish and chips.  Most of the fried foods taste alright depending on when you order it.  If its been sitting under the heat lamp for too long, they aren't crispy anymore.  One thing I like about this place is that they give larger portions when you order fried foods.  Their clam chowder bowls are good too, but nothing amazing.
author: David C.

description:
We snag a small pub table with four chairs and Bella waits in line to purchase a Dungeness crab and fried calamari.  I am immediately reminded why Bella loves this place so much.  It is similar to the "night market" style of eating that is so popular in Taiwan.  For more information on Taiwan's night markets: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_markets_in_Taiwan.

While Bella is away a troupe of five grotesque foreigners move in on our table.  Without a mere acknowledgement of my existence the two women sit while the men stand.  All begin shoving their grubby paws into various boxes of seafood and cramming the food into their faces.  One blonde haired woman ate as sloppily as a wild boar, talking loudly and spraying food chunks across what was -- "our table".  The wild boar and a male companion keep eyeing the backpack that is reserving Bella's seat.  One grubby paw touches it and I'm -- "getting medieval on their asses".  

I realize that this is communal dining but one iota of common courtesy would be greatly appreciated.  Bella returns and is clearly not a fan of the foreigner troupe blocking her from reaching her seat.  She forces her way in, throwing those skinny pointy elbows and sets the food on the table.  I slide one of our boxes of food, slamming it into their box of food in order to clear some room for us to eat.  The fried calamari was UN-BE-LIEV-ABLE.  You won't find it this good at four and five star restaurants.  It is tender, plump and delicious.  The crab is pretty tasty as well.  Bare in mind this was over the 4th of July weekend so part of the drama we brought upon ourselves.  Be prepared to eat on a park bench, sidewalk or curbside if it is the high tourist season.
author: David E.

description:
I HATE TOURISTS

But I love The Crab Station at the Fisherman's Wharf. I've ordered a shrimp cocktail and a chowder. Enjoyed both. Definately a spot to drop by and grab something while walking the Pier. PS: don't get scared by the Bush Man. haha
author: Jane A.

description:
Well hello there my lovely clam chowder, you were really delicious and I must say I cheated on boudin because I simply just cannot stop my self from having you. Haha

Clam chowder in a bread bowl = delicious
Fish&chips for the BF = so-so 
Their fries was cold but still good.

Total:$15+ a bit expensive because it mostly attracts tourists with sh*t load of moolah. :)

-1 for the guy who gave us the order because he didn't understand us.
author: Anna P.

description:
Food here seemed pretty average.  They give you pretty good sized portions, but none of it was really that fresh.  Of course food isn't made to order so that's to be expected.

Their clam chowder had a very strong clam flavor to it which if you like you'd probably like it.  

The only really good thing is the dungeness crab, but its super easy to buy at a chinese supermarket and steam it yourself.  

So really this place is possibly somewhere you just get a quick bite to eat...like a seafood mcdonalds except everything is 25 minutes old.
author: Russ N.

description: Ate at crab station number 2. Tiny. Fast. Off tasting clam chowder in my opinion. Rather go to boudin.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
This place is so gross. 
How could anyone give this place 4 stars? I am really amazed because the quality of the food that is served here is rather disgusting.  My significant other and I came across this place and bought fried calamari, bread bowl clam chowder, and a corn dog.  I've never spent $4.00 on a freaking fosters farms corn dog, EVER until I came to this P.O.S. place.  This place is run by cheapster Chinese that rips you off on food that isnt made from scratch and sold at Safeway. I could buy a whole box of corndogs at Safeway for $4.00 and it won't taste as bad as this crap from CRAP STATION.  

Also, as a previous yelper below wrote how she saw two cans of Campbells Clam chowder cans... I WOULDN'T DOUBT THAT THIS PLACE BUYS THEIR CRAP FROM SAFEWAY AND MARK UP THEIR FOOD BY 4000%! Their soup was watery as hell and BLAND! No clams whatsoever-- the cheap shit that you get at a public school cafeteria on a budget!

Their calamari THE MOST DISGUSTING THING OF ALL.  it was dry, oily, and cold with marinara sauce that was watery, bland and gross.  I could've just opted for the restaurants in front and spent my money on better quality food.  If I were you, i'd stay farrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr awayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy from Crap Station!
author: Ping Y.

description: This place is the best! Great fish and chips, bomb shrimp, and the cheapest whole crabs made me rate it at 5 stars. Try a whole steamed crab for about 13 bucks depending on the weight. Anywhere else a whole crab will cost you 30 bucks.
author: Francisco A.

description:
This place is awesome! When we're down here, I HAVE to come here every time. Yes I said it, EVERY time. They make just about the best clam chowder in a bread bowl known to man kind. On top of that they serve the freshest of fresh crab/shrimp sandwich. This is probably only place need to go to get your sea food. I've also tried the the calamari here before aka fish and chips, boy is the food here great. You will never ever be disappointed if you come here and you love sea food.

For one thing this place is always rushed so don't expect to get the best service here, there are a bunch of people coming in and out and workers just walking around squashed in their little station, but they always seem to get everything thing done right when you ask for it. It does get a bit crowding especially around this are as there are a bunch of competing stations literally right next door. On a weekend, be careful there are even twice as more people with all the tourists and such. 

If you're around the Warf, please stop by this Crab Station to eat some "authentic" sea food. If you can't seem to get to this specific spot there are others right next to it, try e'm they're just as good as well, but I still recommend this place instead. My favorite spot for some yummy chowder.
author: William S.

description: This was one of the better crab cakes I had on the wharf. Not too much filler and lots of crab. Came with some fries for under $4. Yum.
author: Chris O.

description: I know this is a tourist spot but they still make damn good food! I'm from the East Coast originally and this place had phenomenal clam chowder -  better than anything NYC had to offer and the best I had outside of Boston. Their fried stuff is yum too. Stoop to dem tourists' level and check it out, yo.
author: Bill C.

description: I love to eat crab.  If you want to be a tourist for a day and too lazy to cook your own, come down to fisherman's wharf and chow down on some steamed crab here.  Came down here with my in-laws to get some fresh air.  We took a pit stop here before having dinner to enjoy some crab, and boy was it heaven.  Order one whole steamed crab to split among three (even though I ate three-fourths of it) fresh, and savor the taste.  This place has seating, even though it's tight.  The staff here are nice and friendly.  Plus, they validate parking....one hour free at the parking lot across from this restaurant.  So we ended paying $9 for 3 hours instead of the $3 every 20 minutes.  I hightly recommend avoiding the fried clams...I couldn't find the clams in the dish...even though I found it quite addictive to chew on batter.
author: Lisa W.

description: Had the clam chowder bowl and fried shrimp with fries.  Everything tasted decent.  The only thing is that it is really crowded here.  There is really no place to eat if you order to-go.  There is a small table area in the front for you to stand up and eat, besides that, you just have to find a spot on the street and eat.  We were lucky to grab the small table right out front of the store, but it was so dirty.  People left their nasty crab shells and stuff all over the table.  The person who worked there just wiped everything to the floor and that was it.  Another thing is I'm not too sure how sanitary this place is because all the food is out in the open.
author: Sw H.

description: After wasting my time and money on crab at a seafood restaurant, I decided I was still hungry. After walking around the wharf for a few minutes I decided to go to the Crab Station. I was shocked that I only had to pay 13 dollars for a half pound crab. My food took awhile, but it was well worth it. The crab was much bigger than I expected and the guy did a great job chopping up my crab. As someone who loves crab I highly recommend this place next time you are at the wharf.
author: Kevin N.

description: fast service.  great crab sandwiches, chowder, fried calamari and shrimp.  fair prices.  been awhile.  will recommend
author: Rich H.

description: the street vendors are all pretty much the same, and I don't have complaints either way- Crab- delicious although messy, shrimp- YUMMMMM, and of course the soup in the bread bowl is a must!  One thing i must say, the crabs were tastier when they boiled them when they were alive right in front of you! I don't care what everybody says, there's no difference in killing them first and then cooking for you, or just dropping them into a boiling pot of water. DAMN PETA activists! Either way, if you're hungry and you think you can handle eating a crab without a table and just standing, DO IT!
author: Meena N.

description: I make it a ritual to stop by Fisherman's wharf every time I am in SF for some crabs and calamari at the crab stands now. I am totally a fan..if not yet addicted to it. I would totally come here weekly if it's not an hour away and my wallet really permits it. I like this stand here because it has a little shop in front of it with seating inside. The crab here is good and they actually gave you the full thing..including the crab shell/body. At the other stand, I notice that they would throw the body shell away. I would actually just get the clam chowder and crab here and would walk down 2 stands down to get the fried calamari there. Each stand has their own cocktail sauce so you can really taste the difference buying food at different stand. This place is totally a treat..be prepared to get your hands dirty though.The provide wipes I don't think it was helpful.  But don't worry, you can wash it off by walking to the bathroom near Boudin bakery to wash it off...but the lines there are never short!
author: Ngoc L.

description:
I suppose I'm writing this review for my grandma really.. 

as she demands a stop at the Crab Station whenever she's visiting. The crab is waaaaay expensive (average $25 per crab, like the one you see in the picture), but at least it's fresh and made to order. It's actually kinda kool to watch them toss these crabs in the huge pot and then  selling them non-stop to the line of customers waiting impatiently.

If you stand at the counter behind the shop, they will give you as much butter and sauce as you want, just don't expect too much "customer service" because these guys are literally handling ten things at once. The crabs are generally pre-cracked, but if you're one that needs utensils, I suggest you bring your own as they don't provide them.
author: Jade T.

description:
For the mere experience of being at Fisherman's Wharf and eating a bread bowl filled with clam chowder I'd have to give it 5 stars. Tourist trap #900. But, I'm here to review on taste alone. 

So some of you may already know that there is absolutely no place to sit and eat your food once you've ordered it. It's not like a restaurant or a cafeteria. It's more like vendors on the side selling their products. There are sometimes free counter space where you can place your food and eat away, but it's not comfortable at all. Yes, tons of seafood selections galore. Crab Station #2 had: clam chowder, sandwiches; crab, shrimp or seafood mix, fried items; corn dogs, crab cakes, fish and chips, calamari and chips, clam strips and chips, shrimp and chips, seafood cocktails; crab, shrimp, prawn, oyster, squid and lobster. 

My husband and I order the following: (2) bread bowls $5.50/ea., (1) fried calamari and chips $7.75, (1) 1/2 lobster and shrimp cocktail $16.25. A grand total of: $35! Whoo! The lobster wasn't as tasty as I had expected it to be. I mean, I had devoured the lobster I had just a few weeks ago at the Lobster Fest @ San Pedro. Now, that was good and well worth my $17. But not here at Crab Station. The same goes for the clam chowder. As I was eating it, I had thought about how much better Progresso Soup was compared to this. I should have brought a can of that and slabbed it into some bread and I'd be set. Next time, I'll say pass....and maybe try somewhere else.
author: Irma E.

description:
4 stars for the food but, 5 stars for the trip down memory lane...and Anchor Steam.

I remember walking down Fisherman's Wharf when I was kid, with my dad and marveling at the sights.  Honestly, the water stunk and I wasn't feeling the seagulls and tourists back then but, I've grown to appreciate them.  The wharf is one of the few places that can transport me back to my childhood in SF.

Bf and I ordered fish and chips, clam chowder in a bread bowl, two Anchor Steams, and our tab came to about $22.  We were coming off some lackluster SF style seafood in Sac the night before.  There's something about sitting on the sidewalk and inhaling ocean air during your meal that makes it taste better.  The fish was fresh and hot, even burning my tongue a bit.  The chips on the bottom were cold by the time we got to them.  The chowder is as only as SF can make it.  Anchor Steam has a pretty strong after taste but, it beats the commercial watered down beer.

Yes, it's a tourist trap but, it's worth falling into...at least once.
author: Jenny O.

description: it's all right.  typical touristy pressure sales people.  Just because I look like a tourist, doesn't mean that I am going to fall for that stuff.
author: Kat W.

description: On NorCal roadtrip with my Dad. I recognize this is a TOURIST TRAP, but $40 for cooked dungeness crab is absurd. Very rude workers who kept glancing at me and speaking another language in a very uncomfortable, condescending talking-about-the-customer kind of manner. As Daddy's girl, I wanted to buy him a local food to try and I did. They even had the nerve to stop my Dad and his friend from entering the shop to eat at table. For rude service all-around come here. We were pressed for time.
author: T M.

description:
Since I can't remember all of their names, this review is more of a general review for most of the crab stalls on the row.

I will agree that none of their clam chowders stand out, nevertheless they are the perfect companion on a chilly, foggy SF morning. 
I am however, a big fan of the crab sandwhiches!!!!!!!
Truthfully, I am biased because the nostalgia associated with these sandwiches reminds me of when my boyfriend and I first started dating and would retreat to the city to "get lost" eat a crab sandwich and watch the sea lions. 

Food-wise alone: most of the sandwiches are generously portioned and are a light and flavorful break from your franchise Subways. I personally love them!

The crowds, the freshly cooked crabs, the flocks of birds, the lack of seating and the street performers are all part of the street-side ambiance so I don't complain. It's very touristy but I'll deal if it means I can have my sandwich!
author: Ellen Mae V.

description: Awesome sandwich! However, it is crab salad, similar to chicken salad. I was expecting a hot crab s/w...ooops. It was delicoius and I would defintiely go back.
author: Phillip G.

description:
I got the fish and chips and the fish was excellent--mostly fish and not batter! My boyfriend got the seafood mix sandwich and loved it. The clam chowder was also excellent. 

I would have given them 4 stars, but the food was not as warm as I would have liked.
author: Aesah L.

description: It's cheaper than any other crab station nearby. The calamary was delicious, a must try if you go around here! The fish and chips and crab cake were good. However the clam chowder and crab cocktails were not good and I didn't want to order that again. No place to sit and they served the food very fast.
author: Allentine T.

description: Clam chowder in a bread bowl plus a beer for under $11. Can't beat it.
author: Marshall J.

description:
umm.... fish is smelly!  Here's what my owners had to say:

"What can be said about eating seafood on the public street?  It's everything you'd expect from a streetside stand, so I am not even going to consider complaining about cleanliness, decor, facilities, etc.  Let's talk food!  I had the clam chowder in a sourdough boule - AMAZING!  and for less than six bucks, this huge serving is WELL worth it!  I also had a shrimp cocktail.   This was quite good (how can you screw up a plain shrimp cocktail?)   Extra points for friendly staff and lightning fast service!  They have cans of beer, too!" - Dirkie

"Being partial to our friends of the sea, it turned my stomach to see them being prepared.  However, the food was pretty extraordinary.  The best clam chowder I've had in a very long time.  The bread for the boule was a very good, traditional San Franciscan sourdough.  A MUST for anyone who is visiting The City!  (pay attention to the signs for metered street parking.  After a certain time of day, for us it was 7:00, the parking is free!)"   - Johnny
author: Chien V.

description: This place hits the spot with our clam chowder and calamari craving.
author: Bruce P.

description: A little disappointed at the chowda here. Shared a bowl with some buds pre-dinner style, but definitely expected more in terms of quality and taste. Don't get me wrong, it was good, just not spectacular. Seemed a bit watery as I tend to like mine a bit thicker. Good amount of clams and potatoes though.
author: Peter D.

description:
clam chowder in a bread bowl is decent.. it can be thicker

fish and chip was ok

large crab seafood and shrimp salad was not worth the price.  it's over $13 but mostly small small shrimp, 2 med size one and some shredded crab.  None of it taste fresh....

portion is on the small side for the price but it's in middle of tourist area.  one nice thing is they have a small sitting area so won't have to eat the food standing ....
author: Coco L.

description:
Clam chowder in a bowl for $5.50? 

Dang. That's cheap.

And really tasty and fast! Served steaming hot and fresh!

Just the way it should be =D. 

Love the setting too! This is the PROPER way to eat at the Pier! Forget sitting in a restaurant!
author: Gail N.

description: Clam chowder and crab sandwich. $15.95.  I should have heeded all the warnings about eating on Fisherman's Wharf (save for a few choice spots).  I didn't and I paid for it.  This was the first of three spots we attempted for lunch the other day and it was horrible.  I'm not afraid of street food or food trucks, having spent over four years in Thailand and devouring food served to me in plastic bags, I'm not afraid of questionable food origins...for the most part.  The soup was served in a bread bowl and was watery and fishy tasting.  Toss.  The crab sandwich was also fishy tasting and the baguette it was served in could double for a brick.  I took one bite and...you guessed it...toss.  Don't waste your money.
author: Jean S.

description: Went here because I was passing through SF and I wanted something fast and cheap.  Got the fried calamari/clam combo as well as the "fresh" shrimp/crab meat combo.  Spent $20 on this.  Fried stuff was generic...something you could get anywhere...overpriced.  The "fresh" shrimp and crab meat had no flavor whatsoever.  Was most likely "fresh frozen."  The cocktail sauce didn't taste like cocktail sauce.  It tasted more like ketchup mixed with some paprika.  Felt very ripped off after this meal.   Food was passable, but not worth the price.
author: Sushi X.

description: Situated right in the heart of Fisherman's wharf is where you'll find Crab Station #2.  I must admit we walked around the block looking at all the menus and this stand had a huge line.  We decided to try it because all the Asian tourist were crammed around the booth.  The seafood is fresh but the crab sandwich had a little too much mayo for my tastes.  The bread was chewy and plain.  For the next go around, I'd opt for a place that sold the sandwich on a sourdough roll.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Definitely a San Francisco experience. If you are at Fisherman's Wharf you have to go here. Crab stations are on the street but #2 has its own sitting area inside and they charge you the same price. The other stations that have their own sitting area charge 2x the price.  So don't get ripped off. If you are into fancy restaurants and touristy places, this not for you. 

The lady inside was surpringly very friendly not what you would expect from Chinese service. But only her, the guys are typical Chinese style with no smile and don't pay attention to what you need. 

The food was very good. Definitely the best we have had here in SF. My wife really wanted crabs and seafood and she was really happy. She was more satisfied here then at the crab house on pier 39 and R & G lounge.

We had 2 whole crabs, 1/2 lb shrimp and 4 drinks only for $60. Can't beat that anywhere. Too bad we didn't have more time to come back and try the clam chowder in the bread bowl. We found this place on the last night in SF.
author: Thuy P.

description: Clam chowder in a bread bowl was pretty good.  The bread was soft.  The chowder itself wasn't the best, but who cares when It's being sopped up by a bread bowl and eaten like a folded up sandwich toward the end?  The chunky potatoes and addition of oyster crackers, tapatio, salt, and pepper added that extra umph.
author: Elise G.

description: Who would have thought the best clam chowder I've ever had was from a street vendor rather than a restaraunt! It was amazing as well as the dungeoness crab!
author: Ian R.

description: their clam chowder is partly made from campbells clam chowder soup. Me and my husband was there a week ago and sat at the mini bar inside their store. WE saw a box of campbells inside their kitchen(the big canned ones). their door going to the kitchen is only covered with a curtain so you can actually see what goes on inside whenever a staff comes out to replenish a food that they serve. When I saw that My taste buds remembered the taste of canned clam chowder from campbells and Yes it really does taste like it!! I don't know guys but after seeing something like that will make any tourist disappointed. but maybe... just maybe... they cook it half campbells and half from scratch. The chowder was not as good as the ones from it's neighbors. don't eat their clam chowder! their calamari and chips(fries) is very good though, it was devoured immediately! their crab sandwich tasted kinda funky, suffice it to say it wasn't fresh and not well seasoned.
author: Jayne C.

description: Do yourself a solid, and go on a major holiday (not the 4th) quick and easy. Pay attention to the people (ahem, tourists) in line in front of you- if they aren't moving/paying attention holler your order and it arrives before your eyes in seconds. (seriously, the staff will appreciate it) Bring cash, and order the bread bowl. Nothing like the chain down the street, but you get more than you pay for. (Corn dog, fries and bowl-under 10 bucks!) Quality? I, personally LOVED the fresh (?) tasting chowder...spices were right on. Corndog? Was a corn dog. Come enjoy the people watching and eating off the stations! (standing only- but very cool)
author: Rosemary W.

description: Great prices!  Live dungeness crabs are killed, steamed or boiled, then cracked in front of you.  It couldn't get any better if you preferred freshness.
author: Cathaleya C.

description:
This is one of the seafood stands at Fisherman Wharf...honestly I don't see or taste the difference between all of them..We've had Sabella so thought we'd try this one. Got the crab cake ($3.50 and came with some fries...meh) not sure how much crab's actually in it coz it's all grounded up...also had the seafood sandwich...now that was yummy...and of course the chowder coz it's just good to have in the type of weather we were having...

eating at these stalls kinda have that street food feel you get when you travel to asian countries :)
author: Jenny C.

description:
It's hit or miss here, but mostly hit. I live for the days that there are live crabs for me to request to be cooked. DIE CRABS DIE. 

Seriously though, these guys are accommodating to the max and will fill every request possible. Make sure you ask for a live crab if they have them. 

Sure there are tourists everywhere, but just wear sunglasses at night to distinguish yourself. Bring a 40 in a paper bag and drink it with you crab on the broken up benches at the marina. You won't look like a tourist anymore!

I also had the funniest memory while eating a crab here. I was sitting at a table along the marina on a windy day. All of the sudden, the wind picked up our plate full of crab shells and flung them into the face of an oncoming biker. Perfect timing! Mother Nature is a bitch. 

Oh Crab Station. How do you satisfy my every need so well?
author: Ryan V.

description: All I can say about this clam chowder is that it's A-Ok.  They have two tables inside the corridor which are usually used during busy hours.  I think I can get the same clam chowder at Souplantation just without the sourdough bread.  Good prices on beer if you want to chug a Corona with your soup.  The clam chowder hits the spot but not with awesomeness though.
author: Camilo G.

description:
Out of all the stations on that spot...I always go back to #2!
Seems to have the best, consistant seafood! Always has a seafood sandwich, calamari, crab of course, etc!!! 

We're just spoiled to live in the city and get fresh seafood..BAM RIGHT IN OUR BACKYARD!

And people just park in the 10 minute parking, if ya got an SUV pop the back and eat in there!! WE DO IT! (and if I don't find parking there next time, I'm deleting this review LMAO)  

(for the tourist...apart of the experience is sitting across the street, avoiding the seagulls, listening to the musician, people watch, smell the ocean air and take it all in!)
author: M R.

description:
The strip along where this restaurant is located is seafood shack heaven. I was in the mood for clam chowder but this shop and the other ones literally right next to it all served them! I ended up picking this one because it had a cute picture of a crab on it's store sign...yes I know that makes me lose all credibility but I had too many options damn it! 

The clam chowder tasted good but nothing that wowed me. It was only a little bit better than progresso canned soup, but it did have a nice creamy taste and wasn't too salty. It was also pretty cheap by SF food standards ($5.50), but it was the same price as 4 other seafood shacks next door.

The next time I'm the area I will be trying out the other seafood shacks.
author: Will M.

description:
I am not sure which place served me my food, because there are a whole string of them by the Fisherman's Wharf here. I ate the crab sandwich, but it was pretty darned good, and add to that the clam chowder, and this girl is in heaven. There just is something about seafood that gets my juices going. Now stop that - I mean gastric juices. I love seafood. 

If you love or like or crave seafood, this is THE place to come and get some fresh.
author: Zuki J.

description: Crab Station #2 and the original Crab station are essentially the same place.  The guys who work this booth are a little pushy.  Their chowder is not cream based, or if it is they dilute it so much that you can't tell.  The bread bowl it was served in was great though!  My friend got the mixed sandwich, and the crab part of it was full of shell.  The bread for her sandwich was also hard, like it for sure wasn't fresh. The price was right and we were in a hurry.  I probably won't eat here again.
author: Jennifer L.

description: We have tried the Shrimp and Chips, Calamari and Chips, Clam Chowder Bread bowl, and the Mixed Seafood Sandwich.  The food is amazingly fresh and cheap!  The only problem is the seaguls...they see you with food and they will hunt you down...one of them actually swooped down as we were walking away from the stand and almost took the tray out of my wife's hands...but if you are aggressive and kick the crap out of those birds they will go away lol  Also the bread can be a little chewy.
author: Carlos U.

description:
This was the first place I had crab in San Francisco. it was cold as hell and I think that's what made the steamed crab and clam chowder taste even better . Last I remembered I think the set-up is somewhat like a kiosk-type operation that sells Crab by the pound, Shrimp Coctail, Shrimp Salad, Fried Shrimp, Calamari. 

if you get the crab, ask them to steam it and  prepare it for you. The guy will use this little hammer to crack the crab for you and it almost sounds like hes making music.

Dont forget about the drawn butter too.. Good stuff
author: Henry R.

description: The touristy thing to do.  Good, cheap (for SF) seafood.  Grab a beer and sit n eat.
author: Darrell S.

description:
The crab was fresh, sweet, and extremely delicious.  They do a really good job cracking the crab for you, so you can get all of it out.  They give you cocktail sauce, which was entirely unnecessary, and many many lemon slices.  They also serve the crab on a large plate, which makes it easier to separate the crab and not drip on yourself.

Make sure to ask for napkins, because they don't give them to you by default.
author: Angel S.

description: So disappointed after reviews. Very expensive. Got the combo coctail. Crab was meh. Packed with tasteless little bay shrimp. Crab House way better, and priced the same. Price said one thing, then they charged me an additional 50 cents. Why, I have no idea, I just went with it.
author: Scott G.

description: The crab was not very fresh at all, I would not come back here again. In general these crab stands to me are not very fresh. I would rather go some where & pick out my own crab & steam it right then & there to get the freshest crab. Besides you don't know how long those precooked crabs have been sitting out.
author: Cammie T.

description: Went here on a weekend when the wharf is always packed with people (bad idea). I had the clam chowder bowl. It was good but not mmm mmm good. The crab sandwich was also ok. I think they use too much mayo. I'll try the next restaurants or stalls first serving clam chowders before coming back to this one.
author: Alma M.

description: I got Crabs here. No, actually I didn't, I just always wanted to say that without having to back it up with whatever painful remedy goes with having shellfish crawl all over my genitals. Ok, weird guy there... Actually this is my spot to come down to, grab a pint of clam chowder, a crab cake and an anchor steam. Load them up in a pile, then walk around the corner and watch the world famous Bushman scare the shit out of unwitting tourists. Pure Frisco at its finest, I don't think I'll ever get tired of this, what can I say? I'm a man of simple pleasures...
author: Artimus I.

description:
Since I wasn't too content with my last trip to Fisherman's Wharf for clam chowder, I decided to try a different stand/kiosk at the Grotto in hopes of finding something better.

I couldn't figure out the name of Crab Station at Fisherman's Wharf at first because the menu I ordered off of had chinese writing on top (I realized looking at my receipt that it's the same stand as the one next to it).  

I'd rate Crab Station as a 3.5 but rounded up because of their generosity in their serving portions.  I wouldn't say that they have the best clam chowder, but it's still pretty good and has chunks of potatoes and clams (unlike stingy places).  They also serve more chowder in their bread bowls than other's I had seen where the bread was barely carved out to hold the soup.

We ordered a 2-item seafood combo for $9.95, which is already a good price for a variety of seafood.  But to my surprise, our order came with about 8-10 pieces of very large and tasty fried shrimp--like you actualy taste the shrimp, and it's not just some skinny shrimp dipped in copious amounts of batter.  

The calamari was really good too and it came in a heaping serving almost spilling out of the 2 paper plates they served it to us in.  I didn't feel ripped off here at all (as I have from other places at Fisherman's Wharf--read past review).  They also gave me a free second serving of cocktail sauce without charge :)

I'm still on the lookout for the best clam chowder at Fisherman's Wharf, but I'm definitely coming back here for the seafood (and to try their steamed crab).
author: Ashley S.

description: Tastiest non fancy crab I've ever had!  No fuss inside seating across from outside station.
author: Wakako U.

description: The price is about right for the quality and portions. Good, but not great. Good service, they were very polite and quick.  Nice for a quick bite.
author: Hasan And Erin L.

description:
So my trip in San Francisco so far is not going as expected AT ALL, but I'm soldiering on and making the best of it.

As they say, Clam Chowder in a bowl of Sourdough bread from a booth on Fisherman's Wharf is something you MUST do. 

They're right. 

From this booth in particular it's $5.50. (That's the same for the other 4 or 5 booths next to it) One salt, one pepper and a bag of crackers. Make sure to mix them all together. Eat a spoonful, then dip a piece of the breadbowl "hat" in it. 

It could be a great way to start or end your San Francisco experience (or a reminder of how lucky you are to live there). Don't take it with you to your hotel room, the only proper way to eat it is if you sit or stand around and watch the sights and hear the sounds of the Wharf. 

Oh, and make sure you know where a bathroom is and carry some gum or mints with you, it's very smelly.
author: Philippe C.

description:
see my review on a duplicate listing of this place...

http://www.yelp.com/biz/fishermans-wharf-chowder-and-crab-sidewalk-stands-san-francisco#hrid:7iTEpj8gVrjzcKW5U-Ihmw
author: Sara C.

description: I came two weeks ago on a late Sunday evening. The place was bustling with people trying to place orders and trying to get their food. I wanted calamari but they were out of it. So, I ordered the clam chowder. It was salty. At first I thought it was the crackers that contained too much salt. I tasted the crackers alone and it wasn't salty at all. It was the clam chowder that was salty. The clam chowder was not good at all. It was the first time that I didn't finished my clam chowder. Honestly, the canned Progesso clam chowder at my house tasted a lot better.
author: Linh N.

description: came here after the Ghirardelli chocolate festival with a couple of friends abd had the fried calamari. D-F'ing-licious! Side of the best calamari I've ever had, maybe it was the batter or maybe the calamari itself was fresh, alls I know is that it was very good. And it was a generous helping enough for 2 people while still being under $10. Just pick this up and plop down on the curb for a great outdoors snack!
author: Jerald B.

description:
love this place for fresh steammed crab!

you can pick a fresh crab.. yup.. pick one that is still moving around and tell them you want that one. They will mark it for you, ( tie a rubberband around the claw) and throw it in the steamer... 18 mins later, you have a fresh crab. they will crack it for you and pack it if you want to bring it home.

eating there is a lil messy, but fun!
author: Anna T.

description:
1st visit for the three of us on 12/28/2010.
Overall we're very disappointed.  The crab sandwich was particularly surprising since boxes and boxes of (what I would assume to be fresh) live crab were being used by all the sidewalk stands this day.  We will not be going back.  

Here's a breakdown.

Crab Sandwich - ~$7
Overall bland, crab meat seemed not really that fresh with little crab flavor.  Bread was totally bland.  The whole thing was one big white blob of stuff.
Overall:  Yuk!

Calamari & Chips - ~$9
Chips and meat both warm to cold.
Meat had what appeared to be freezer burns.
Meat flavor so-so at best.
Chips unremarkable.
Overall:  We've had much better at numerous locations in CA for similar cost.

Fish & Chips - ~$9
Chips warm to cold.
Fish was hot, but the breading wasn't tasty and it was very thick, so not helping the experience much.  The fish was well cooked and tasty.
Overall:  We've had much better at numerous locations in CA for similar cost.

Clam Chowder - ~$4
So-so flavor at best.  Glad we got just the cup.
Overall:  Not a chance.  We've had real "chowdah" in New England and this does not compare.  Get a can of "Snows" brand from Safeway for a better chowder.

Prawn Cocktail - ~$5
About 5 medium/large prawns in a cup with a side of cocktail sauce.
Prawns seemed to be previously frozen; not de-veined either.
Overall:  Well, ... No.

Other
- Nice staff.
- We had to ASK for lemon.  Seriously?  But they did give us a boatload.
- Unlimited and tasty cocktail sauce.
- Portions typically large to very large (sandwich).
author: Picky P.

description: This was our first stop when we rolled into town after checking into our hotel. It was kinda late and we went to the alley where the real stuff was and got some chowder and calamari. The chower in the sourdough bread bowls were BOMB! Yum - I so loved it. The calamari was good too, but considering it's fried...super greasy. My daughter was a little grossed out but it wouldn't have mattered where it came from! The cocktail sauce that they have is phenomenal! The guys that worked there were attentative and got us our food quickly, my only down side to the visit was that my stomach is not use to the grease and I got ridiculously sick in the middle of the night with an upset stomach...that was a bummer.
author: Stacey A.

description: Excellent crab sanwiches, a little too much green onion but did mind too much. 4 stars!
author: Lo L.

description: clam chowder in a bread bowl is the best when youre by the bay or some sort of body of water...haha...for me at least. the chowder was filled with the perfect amount of clams. the bread would be good if they toasted it, but looking at how busy they were, that would've taken way too long. all in all, a decent place to get clam chowder in a bread bowl for 5.50...i think that's typically how much it runs around the pier.
author: Anna S.

description: Walked by here and the guy just started talking to me in Chinese.  I guess he assumed all Asians can only speak in Chinese?  Anyways, decided to get crab at this place because they let you sit in their indoor shack for the same price.  The crab was delicious.  The next day, I tried the fried calamari, and it was just okay.  Not particularly awesome, but you do get a lot!  Definitely stop by to try the crab but I think the fried food can be a hit or miss depending on how long they've been sitting out.  And the fact that you can sit inside for the same price is a plus.  The other places down the same stretch wanted to charge $31 for the same type of crab if you sat inside versus it being $11.95/lb if you were to buy it off the street.
author: Cindy W.

description: Yes!!!! Good cheap crab cakes! They taste sooooo yummy!!!!!!!
author: Joseph C.

description: OMG! Best fried seafood ever! Clam chowder was choice! The only thing that sucks are the chips(fries)...The calamari...the shrimp...the baby octopus( or squid) was crisped to perfection! Avoid the over priced food everywhere...pay half the price and eat here...unless you want to have a nice pricey meal than by all means...but if you take delight in the more simple street food this is the place to go... Anthony Bourdain status!
author: Alexander A.

description: We ended up ordering here so we can sit on the tables. All the stalls pretty much serve the same stuff and they all abide by the market price. This place gave us a deal because we ordered so much stuff. The crab meat and shrimp cocktail was delicious. The whole crab was an experience indeed, make sure you ask for extra crab heads because that is where all the flavor lies. The crab sandwich was awesome. I will come back to this place because the lady in there knows us already and we probably will get good deals in the future.
author: EJay D.

description: It's hell and half to be a local walking through the crab area of Fisherman's Wharf no matter what, but this place helps ease the pain if you want to grab a fresh crab to eat quickly.  It's the only spot that has a small interior with two tables and some counter space to sit and eat without paying for waitservice.  It's normally packed, but the turnover is quicker than you'd think, there are no seagulls trying to steal your food and the crabs are totally worth it.
author: Holly M.

description: Crab cocktail, clam chowder, and a beer. Great stuff. Its crowded and hard to find a place to sit, but it was really, good.
author: Daniel L.

description: got some calamari after cruising around alacatraz. mmm good stuff!
author: Kayleeny A.

description: They had ok fish-n-chips. Two meals and bottles water was $19.33. What makes the experience is grabbing the food and eating it while watching the live entertainment. If you are looking for a London newspaper fish-n-chips meal this is not your place. Then again you may be on the wrong continent.
author: Chad N.

description: This only reviews the shrimp cocktail.  $9 for two.  Looked and tasted like old frozen shrimp.  :(    I didn't try it, but the seafood sandwich looked disturbingly GROSS.  As if it would give you days of the shitskis.
author: Nicole G.

description: The clam chowder was pipping hot (and on the cold day I went was really nice), but there weren't that many clams. The crab cake was OK, but I don't have anything to compare it to. For the price, it was a really good value on the Wharf.
author: Brandy G.

description: the best crab in town next to alcatraz the rock
author: Ronald M.

description: I don't know if the one I went to was Crab Station or Crab Station #2, but don't the same people work at both? Anyways.. the service is not quite as friendly as the Vietnamese dude over at Sabella but it sure beats the lazy guy over at Guardino's. At least the guy here took his time to wipe my pint of clam chowder after he made a mess w/ scooping it. He even used TWO paper trays! One while scooping, and a brand new one to put in my paper bag w/ the pint of chowder! He gave me 2 spoons, TWO bags of oyster crackers and multiple napkins! WOW! All that for $7!! LOL. Not cheap, but it sure beats that small little cup for what?? Over $5 at Guardino's? Now the chowder itself was not as good as the canned ones at Guardino's, but it wasn't bad. It was actually very tasty, but a bit on the salty side. I might be back to try their crab cocktails though, because I saw some BIG chunks of crab on top of the mini chunks, unlike Sabella's.
author: Elaine H.

description: The only impressive thing about this place is that there is seating, which is rare. Had the clam chowder that was salty and had few clam pieces. Fish and chips were good. I'd say better than Long John Silver but still not worth the parking and Calories. Prices were the same or more expensive than the neighboring stands.
author: Helen H.

description: For some reason every time i go to the wharf (alot)  this is the only one we go get food at.   I can only think of 2 times that I got crab from somewhere else.   Maybe it's because it's the only spot with a seat - that you don't have to order from the inside restaruant ( granted if it starts getting full i'm taking this review off =) )
author: Joey N.

description: Several of these are cheating and using terrible bagged crab for the crab walk away cocktails.  Not fresh  Tastes like last weeks pancake batter  AWFUL AWFUL  AWFUL  One even did not have claw chucks !!!   Nick's does it right
author: nick s.
